Award.AwardTitle: Project FAST Capacity at UDC's Urban Teacher Academy

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The University of the District of Columbia (UDC) is planning and developing a STEM concentration within its recently-launched Master of Arts in Teaching (MAT) degree program. The concentration is focused on preparing aspiring teachers to meet the state requirements for licensure in Middle School Science in the District of Columbia. The project is developing UDC's capacity in areas that are critical to offering a high-quality teacher preparation program for aspiring middle-school science teachers. Key outcomes for the project include:
1) Ready-to-teach curriculum for a MAT concentration in Middle School Science;
2) Program approval within UDC, and through the state education office;
3) Programmatic materials to wrap around the curriculum; and
4) A strong, engaged network of STEM professionals and partner institutions prepared to support program implementation as adjunct faculty and/or experiential learning partners.

The Urban Teacher Academy at UDC prepares teacher candidates to differentiate instruction for exceptional learners and students building academic language proficiency. The project team includes teacher educators, a special educator, and language development experts in addition to STEM faculty and content experts from partner organizations. Project FAST Capacity is leading to the creation of a well-designed teacher preparation program for middle grades science, tailored to preparing teachers for high-needs urban schools, as well as a strategic plan for recruiting and preparing aspiring teachers from underrepresented minority backgrounds.

Project Firebirds are STEM Teacher (FAST) Capacity
Building Grant

Final Project Outcomes Report

June 2015


The project, “Firebirds Are STEM Teachers -Capacity” (Project FAST Capacity) at the University of the District of Columbia,  focused
on developing UDC’s capacity in areas essential to a high quality teacher
preparation program for aspiring middle-school science teachers.  Project FAST had as its four outcomes:

• Curriculum:  ready-to-teach curriculum for a MAT concentration in Middle School Science

• Curricular Authority: Program approval for the MAT concentration in Middle School Science

• Curricular Supports: Programmatic support materials in place to ‘wrap around’ the rich, rigorous curriculum

• STEM Network: Strong, engaged network of STEM professionals and partner institutions prepared to support program implementation including faculty and mentors and partners for experiential learning.

Project FASTCapacity’s creation of a teacher preparation program in middle-school science, specifically for preparing aspiring teachers from underrepresented minority backgrounds, has poised the University of the District of Columbia (UDC) to admit its first cohort of aspiring middle science teachers for Academic Year 2016.  Partnerships with DC Public DCPS) (and
Public Charter (DCPCS) middle schools provide fertile ground for the growth and development of teachers who understand the context and opportunities urban schools provide.  Our recruitment efforts are targeting under-represented minorities to be trained in cutting edge approaches tailored towards teaching middle grade students who are diverse in terms of culture, language, and learning styles/abilities.  It is anticipated that by attracting and
training this group of teachers for urban middle school settings they will encourage and inspire students, especially minorities, to select career pathways in STEM fields. Achieving this expectation will contribute to a desired societal outcome of having greater percentages of minorities and especially women in STEM careers.
